Award.AwardTitle: The CepOB3b Young Cluster: A New Laboratory for Studying the Role of Environment in Planet Formation and Cluster Evolution
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support a detailed study of the young, relatively nearby stellar cluster Cep OB3. This cluster is one of the only two massive clusters near the Sun. The cluster is found in a large cavity cleared in the parental molecular cloud, indicating that the Cep OB3b is a rare example of a massive cluster at the later stages of gas dispersal. This project will support ground-based observations and numerical simulations needed to understand the age, dynamics and evolution of this massive young cluster. The first goal of this project is to assess whether massive young clusters such as Cep OB3b can survive gas dispersal and evolve into bound open clusters. The second goal is to study emission from regions of circumstellar disks, in order to examine the impact of radiation from the central star and from the local environment on the structure and survivability of these disks.

This project will assist the training of graduate and undergraduate students. The research team plans to create an easily-available database on Cep OB3b, which may facilitate future studies of this region. This and other studies of star formation in massive clusters will help astronomers understand the possible diversity of planetary systems in our galaxy and to understand the conditions that led to our own solar system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Cepheus OB3b is a massive, young star cluster with about 3000 stars and an age of approximatey 5 million years. It is more evolved than the well studied Orion Nebula Cluster. Cepheus OB3b and the Orion Nebula Cluster are the only massive, young clusters within 1 kiloparsec of our sun, yet Cepheus OB3b has been poorly studied to date. The goal of this proposal was to fund an extensive study of this cluster utilizing data across the electromagnetic spectrum, including X-ray data, visible light spectra, and infrared imaging from ground-based and space telescopes. From these data, we can identify the young stars comprising the cluster and measure their basic properties, luminosity, temperature, mass, age, rotation period, velocity, level of stellar activity, and we can search for the presence of proto-planetary disks.

The intellectual impact is twofold. With regards to star clusters, one of the major issues is understanding "infant mortality", the low rate at which young star clusters survive the disruption of their birth cloud. This is thought to arise from the expansion of the cluster after 80% of the mass - which is in the form of gas - is dispersed. What we don't understand is why some clusters survive dispersal while others do not. To understand this dichotomy, we need to study clusters during the gas disruption phase like Cepheus OB3b. This cluster is organized into two sub-clusters, and we find that the two sub-clusters show different fates. The sub-cluster which has formed a massive O-star is unbound and expanding. In contrast, the sub-cluster which has only formed less massive B-stars is likely to be bound. Thus, this work underscores the importance of the mass of the most massive star in determining whether a cluster survives gas dispersal. Furthermore, it shows that during gas dispersal, a young cluster may produce both an expanding association of stars and a bound cluster.

The factors that control stellar activity are also an area of great interest. We use the enhanced stellar activity of young stars to identify them using X-ray and H-alpha measurments. Stellar activity may also influence the formation of planets via the affect of X-rays on protoplanetary disks and later on, after planets form, determine the habitability of planets. The question is what properties of a star determine stellar activity, as measured by X-ray emission from coronae and H-alpha emission from chromospheres. Our work shows that the X-ray and H-alpha emission from young stars scales almost linearly with the surface area of the photosphere. We find little dependence on the effective temperature of the star, its rotation period, and - in the case of X-rays - the presence of a disk. Thus, the size of a star is the primary determinant of activity, at least for rapidly rotating, young stars. 

The are several areas of broader impacts.  First, star clusters are an important tracer of star formation in distant galaxies; however, to understand these distant star clusters, we must understand the processes that control the fates of nearby star clusters that we can study in detail.  This study has produced important insights into the evolution of star cluster that can be applied to studies of star formation in distant galaxies.  Second, stellar activity of stars has potentially an important impact on the formation of planetary systems and the habilitability of those planets.  Again, this study has produced an important insight into the factors that determine stellar activity.  Finally, this cluster will also be an impotant laboratory for the evolution of disks and the formation of planetary systems.  The data collected by this program can be used for such studies and should have a continuing impact on studies of planet formation.  In addition, this grant has led to the training of two graduate students and three undergraduate students in observational astronomy, with the attendent skills in analyzing spectroscopic and imaging data, developing software for data analysis and modeling, and applying the scientific method to understanding complex phenomena.
